UI Library - Visibility

Visibility Classes

Visibility classes let you show or hide elements based on screen size or device orientation. You can also use visibility classes to control which elements users see depending on their browsing environment.

Visibility classes use !important to ensure they aren't overriden by more specific selectors. This is the only component in the framework that uses !important.

Generic Hide Classes

.l-hide-all and .l-show-all classes are breakpoint independent. You can use them wherever you need.

Hide by Screen Size

.l-hide-tiny, .l-hide-small, .l-hide-medium, .l-hide-large, .l-hide-xlarge classes are breakpoint aware. They will hide an element for a specific screen size.

Example

This block will be hidden on tiny screen sizes.

This block will be hidden on small screen sizes.

This block will be hidden on medium screen sizes.

This block will be hidden on large screen sizes.

This block will be hidden on xlarge screen sizes.

Show by Screen Size

.l-show-tiny, .l-show-small, .l-show-medium, .l-show-large, .l-show-xlarge classes are breakpoint aware. They will show an element for a specific screen size.

Example

The screen SIZE is:

TINY

SMALL

MEDIUM

LARGE

XLARGE

Orientation Detection

.h-show-for-landscape, .h-show-for-portrait classes are breakpoint aware. They will show an element for a specific screen orientation.

Example

The screen ORIENTATION is:

LANDSCAPE

PORTRAIT

Accessibility

Adding one of the .h-hide-xxx classes to an element will prevent screen readers from reading it. However, there are techniques to hide content while still making it readable by screen readers. Class .show-for-sr will be visually hidden but still allowing assistive technology to read it.

Example

Press TAB to see how a hidden block is shown when it gets focused.

YOU HAVE AN SCREEN READER

THIS IS HIDDEN UNTIL FOCUS

Hide for Screen Readers Only

To hide text from assistive technology, while still keeping it visible, add the attribute aria-hidden="true". This doesn't affect how the element looks, but screen readers will skip over it.

This text can be seen, but won't be read by a screen reader.
